data.text: Contents
Introduction

To outline the purpose and function of the Children's Outpatient Department and to ensure all staff using the facility understand the philosophy of the department and work as a cohesive team to provide integrated child and family friendly services.

The Children's Outpatient Department is open from Monday to Friday 08:00 to 18:30, outreach clinics are provided at Braintree Community Hospital and St. Peters Hospital in Maldon on a sessional basis.
The main department could also be utilised during the weekend and evenings if activity required an increase in provision.

We aim to provide a facility to see children and young people up to the age of 16 years, the exception is, children with additional needs who are receiving specialist care and who need to be supported through the transition into adult services who may continue to use the facility until this transition is completed.
Scope
To provide an excellent and integrated children's outpatient services for children, young people and their families / carers, where the 18-week pathway is met.
To provide outpatient / ambulatory facilities for children and young people in a child and family friendly environment
The services provided will be compliant with the NSF for Children and Young People and relevant national and local guidelines, in an environment that meets the diverse needs of our service users.
To provide outpatient services for children and young people in a sensitive environment that meets the requirements and addresses issues around privacy and dignity.
To provide a service that meets the needs of children and young people by working together with other agencies to safeguard children using local and national policy and guidelines.
To provide a local facility for children, young people and their families who need to access some of the specialist services available in from tertiary services.
Definitions
Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
The Divisional Manager for Women, Children's Directorate is operationally and financially accountable for service delivery.
The Outpatient Sister has the day to day responsibility for delivering the service .supported by the Lead Nurse for Children and Young People.

The Outpatient Team will remain professionally accountable for their actions. They will work in conjunction with the Divisional Manager and Lead Nurse to ensure that the service is delivered within the confines of the agreed budget and operational requirements. In addition, the Outpatient team will remain accountable for ensuring that they comply with all MSE clinical and documentation guidelines.
Exclusions from the service
It is anticipated that the following services will continue to provide services for children within their specialist clinics.
Young People over the age of  years, with the exception of
Burns / Plastic surgery
Ophthalmic
Ear Nose and Throat and Oral surgery.
Orthopaedic and Fracture Clinic
Workflows
Access
Children, Young People and their families will access the Outpatient department via:
GP referrals through Choose and Book or letter.
Follow up appointments after an in-patient episode.
Follow up appointments for day cases or ward attendees.
Follow up appointment following well baby episode i.e. discharge from maternity services.
Requests from tertiary centres to follow up patients locally either by resident team or visiting teams.
Referral from Community Paediatric Nurses.
Referral from Community Paediatricians.
Referral from Social Services.
Process for referrals made by letter

6.2.1 On receipt of the letter referral the Consultant Paediatrician will grade the urgency of the appointment in the categories of urgent and routine. An urgent appointment will be offered within 10 days and a routine appointment is offered within 8 weeks (since Covid – 12 weeks) of the date of receipt of the referral within documentation.

6.2.2 For cancer and other urgent appointments the parent / carer will be contacted by telephone and a suitable appointment will be booked, giving the family an opportunity to have as much choice as possible within a maximum 2-week timescale.

6.2.3 For routine appointments a letter will be sent to the next of kin with an appointment date and time, the letter will include the option of contacting the department to change the appointment if the date/time is inconvenient.
Process for choose and book referrals

6.3.1 The parent/carer will attend the GP surgery for a consultation, when the decision is made to refer the child/young person, the GP will refer into our RAS (referral appointment system) parents will be sent a letter with a Password to enable them to select the hospital and earliest availability to suit their needs. An appointment will then be posted out to the family from Children's OPD. Families can call in to change the appointment date or time if required.
Goods
6.4.1 Stock levels will be set and managed by the Sister.
6.4.2 NHS supplies will be obtained through normal routes by utilizing the materials management personnel to manage stock control.
6.4.3 Non –stock requisition orders will be managed by the Sister using the normal non stock ordering system.
Key relationships
The Children's Outpatient Departments works closely, but not exclusively with:
Children's Inpatient wards
Children's assessment area
Neonatal Unit
Children's Community Nursing Team
Pharmacy
Psychotherapy team
Radiology
Phlebotomy
Pathology
Physiotherapy and Occupational Therapy
Dietetics
Health Records Centre
Child Psychology and Psychotherapy Services
Safeguarding Children team
Children's Community Paediatricians
Moulsham Grange Children's Centre
Children's Diabetes Team
ECG
EEG
Tertiary Centres including Primary Treatment Centres for children with cancer
Tertiary Centre visiting teams
Training and Development
Social Services
General Practitioners and their support teams
Supplies
Portering
Estates and Facilities
Voluntary Services
Key operational requirements
The department will meet the standard of the Children and Young Peoples' NSF and adhere to the Safeguarding Children Policies and Procedures.

The clinic templates will be agreed between the Consultant and the Divisional manager to give sufficient clinic slots to meet the demands on the service and sufficient time for children and their families to meet their needs.
Clinics must not be cancelled less than 6 weeks before for consultant annual leave / study leave as per trust policy.
There will be a separation of flows from adult patients.
Patient records to be available for planned appointments, if notes are not available a temporary set will be prepared with the last clinic letter, discharge letter or referral letter.

The service must be fair, accessible and meets the needs of everybody, signposting and access must be suitable to meet the needs of all our clients including wide doors for double / triple buggies and family friendly signage
All reception desks should be low enough to allow children to see the faces of the staff sitting behind a desk. Screens are now in place at reception to protect the patients and staff.
The outpatient area will have Consultation / Examination rooms that are child and family friendly.
The waiting rooms will provide separate areas where appropriate facilities can be provided for both young children and adolescents.

For children with cancer or who are immunosuppressed they will be offered separate waiting facilities, either in a consulting room or in the middle waiting room, which will be closed to other patients. These patients also use the back door from the car park to enter the department to avoid the main hospital entrance.

Play facilities will be incorporated into the department both waiting areas and consultation rooms. Toys are not available in the waiting area since Covid, this will be reviewed as per hospital trust guidelines.
Play specialist or nursery nurse will be available to support children and their families during their clinic appointment.
There is appropriate ancillary accommodation including nappy changing area and breast / baby feeding facilities as well as facilities to heat baby milk and food.
Chaperone will be available to meet the requirements of the Chaperone Policy.
Specialist equipment will be stored appropriately to ensure that the environment remains safe for the children and young people.
Separate room needs to be available for nursing staff to weigh children and babies and have a confidential discussion with parents.
Psychotherapy Staff will be given appropriate space and to enable them to meet children in the department in a quiet space where they will be free from interruptions.

Staff will monitor waiting times during every clinic to ensure that the services can be adapted to ensure that children do not have to wait longer than 30 minutes for any appointment except in exceptional circumstances.
Staff will refer to the access policy to ensure that any child who fails to attend for their appointment are appropriately followed up.
Key relationships with other departments

Children and Young People attending the Trust should have an experience that meets their specific needs and complies with the standard set by the NSF for Children and young people - this specific need applies to all departments where the child/ young person visits.
There should be easy access to/from diagnostics/ pharmacy and support services and the journey to other department must be double pushchair friendly.
Key requirements from facilities management (F.M)
7.4.1 Departmental cleaning schedules should be configured to provide adequate cleaning to meet the 85% standard of the  steps audit.
7.4.2 Cleaning should take place at the end of the morning clinic and at the end of the day with ad hoc cleaning during the day as required.
7.4.3 Daily hard facilities support is provided by the Estate and Facilities department
7.4.4 Stores and pharmacy should be delivered at the beginning of the day prior to the start of clinic.
Environment requirements
7.5.1  The department is decorated in a family friendly way that will meet the needs of children from 0 – 16 years of age.
Wayfinding
Signage is clear and identifies children's OPD.
Journeys to other departments must be clearly marked.
Security requirements
There should be a facility in each of the consulting rooms and at reception to enable the clinician to alert security.
An environmental Risk assessment is performed annually to assess the risks to staff, patients and visitors an action plan is available for staff.
Medical records security
All patient records will be managed and stored securely in the children's patient library.
All movement of patient records will be accurately tracked in accordance with the Trust's case note tracking Policy.
All new documentation will be secured into a folder prior to it leaving the department.
All staff must comply with professional bodies' standards of record keeping and MSE clinical record keeping guidelines
All notes/ patient information must be stored in a locked room / cupboard when they are not in use.
Confidential waste must be disposed following the Trust policy for safe disposal.
Manual handling
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Manual Handling Policies.
All staff should receive mandatory training.
Fire safety

The service will be compliant with the Trust's Fire Safety Policy, Fire Evacuation Policy and other local fire plans and procedures (the detail of these items will then be developed as part of the separate Fire Safety Work Programme, as led by the Trust's Fire Officer.)
ICT requirements

All consultation rooms, reception areas, staff base and Sister's office require a network cable, telephone line and PC facilities to enable staff to access all online data. All PCs in each clinic room should have the necessary updated technology to facilitate Attend Anywhere video appointments via the https://england.nhs.attendanywhere.com/login  platform.
All PCs in the department must be networked to a colour printer/ fax/copier
Staffing
Staff profile
All staff working in or using the facilities will be required to work in a way that embraces the philosophy of family centred care.
The Children's Outpatient Sister will be a Children's Trained Nurse and will have overall management responsibility for the effective running of the department.
The Sister will be supported to manage the department by the Divisional Manager / Business manager for Operational issues and the Lead Nurses for clinical issues.
The Sister will be responsible for ensuring that the nursing staff are up to date with all trust policies and procedures, mandatory training and meet their competencies to fulfil their role.

Staffing requirements will be decided by using an appropriate skill mix tool and by agreement with the Divisional Manager / Lead Nurse. This assessment will take into account the skills of the staff to provide and effective service.
A play specialist will be available to support children and their families.
During a clinic session there should always be at least one children's trained nurse on duty and appropriately qualified support worker preferably a trained nursery nurse.
A consultant will be available to support all junior staff undertaking clinic sessions in the department.
Medical students will be welcomed and supported to attend the department, however; children and their families must be given the opportunity to decline their presence.
Student nurses on the children's pathways will be supported in the department by qualified children's nurses with the appropriate NMC mentorship qualification.

The reception staff must be experienced in working with children, and completed their Level 3 Safeguarding Children training, have and an advanced CRB check and have experience and or training in communicating with children.
Training requirements
Staff meet the mandatory training requirements set out by the Trust in the Mandatory Training Policy.
Staff are trained to use all specialist equipment and sign a competency statement following training.
Qualified nursing staff will be trained to provide effective mentorship to student nurses and be on the Trust mentorship register.
Facilities
There is a facility for staff to change into and out of their uniform.
Toilet facilities are available for staff within the clinic environment.
Staff have access to canteen / refreshments during the hours of the clinic.
Staff lockers are provided to ensure safety of personal belongings whilst at work.
Cold water is available at all times for staff and visitors.
Equipment requirements
Please see Appendix
Infection prevention
The service will be delivered in accordance with and compliance to the Trust's Infection Prevention Policies.
Universal Precautions and ANTT (Aseptic Non-touch Technique) are followed.
All equipment is cleaned daily and recorded on the departmental cleaning record.
Staff are monitored for compliance. The service is supported by an Infection Prevention Team
Contingency
Trust policies and local procedures
Major Incident Plan
Consultant and administration staff sickness managed by Divisional Manager
Nursing staff managed by Children's outpatient Sister
IT and phone down time – mobile phones made available to department, clinic appointments paper copies made.
Monitoring and audit
The audit of this policy will be on a yearly basis and will be reviewed at the Divisional Governance Meetings.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)
References

27.1 Department of Health (20030 Getting the right start: National Service Framework for children, Young People and maternity Services. Online at Getting_the_right_start_- _National_Service_Framework_for_Children_Standard_for_Hospital_Services.pdf (publishing.service.gov.uk) [Accessed 6..12.2021]
